content: Singaporean politician (born 1964) **Grace Fu Hai Yien**[a] [DCMG](/wiki/Dame_Commander_of_the_Order_of_St_Michael_and_St_George) (born 29 March 1964) is a Singaporean accountant and politician who has served as the Organising Secretaries of the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) since 2025 and has been serving as [Minister for Sustainability and the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment) since 2020, and [Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations](/wiki/Ministry_of_Trade_and_Industry_(Singapore)) since 2024. A member of the governing [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP), she has been the [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore#Members_of_Parliament) (MP) for the Yuhua division of [Jurong East–Bukit Batok Group Representation Constituency](/wiki/Jurong_East%E2%80%93Bukit_Batok_Group_Representation_Constituency) (GRC) since 2025. She had previously represented the Yuhua division of [Jurong GRC](/wiki/Jurong_Group_Representation_Constituency) between 2006 and 2011 and [Yuhua Single Member Constituency](/wiki/Yuhua_Single_Member_Constituency) (SMC) between 2011 and 2025. An accountant by profession, Fu worked at [Overseas Union Bank](/wiki/Overseas_Union_Bank), [Haw Par Group](/wiki/Haw_Par_Corporation), and [PSA Corporation](/wiki/PSA_International) before entering politics. She made her political debut in the [2006 general election](/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election) as part of the five-member PAP team for [Jurong GRC](/wiki/Jurong_Group_Representation_Constituency) and won. After Yuhua SMC was carved from Jurong GRC, she won reelection there in the [2011 general election](/wiki/2011_Singaporean_general_election) and would do so until 2025. Following the [redrawing of electoral boundaries](/wiki/Electoral_boundary_changes_of_the_2025_Singaporean_general_election) in the [2025 general election](/wiki/2025_Singaporean_general_election), Yuhua SMC was absorbed into [Jurong East–Bukit Batok GRC](/wiki/Jurong_East%E2%80%93Bukit_Batok_Group_Representation_Constituency), where she won reelection as part of a five-member PAP team. Before her appointment as the Minister of Sustainability and the Environment, Fu served as Senior Minister of State for [National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)) and [Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)) between 2008 and 2011, for the [Environment and Water Resources](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_and_Water_Resources) and for the [Information, Communications and the Arts](/wiki/Ministry_of_Communications_and_Information) between 2011 and 2012, [Second Minister for Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Singapore)) between 2012 and 2015, [Leader of the House](/wiki/Leader_of_the_House_(Singapore)) and [Minister for Culture, Community and Youth](/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture,_Community_and_Youth#Ministers) between 2015 and 2020. ## Early life and education Fu was born on 29 March 1964 in Singapore, [then a state in Malaysia](/wiki/State_of_Singapore_(Malaysia)). She was educated at [Nanyang Girls' High School](/wiki/Nanyang_Girls%27_High_School) and [Hwa Chong Junior College](/wiki/Hwa_Chong_Junior_College) before graduating from the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore) in 1985 with a [Bachelor of Accountancy](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Accountancy) with honours degree in 1985. She subsequently completed a [Master of Business Administration](/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration) degree at the [NUS Business School](/wiki/NUS_Business_School) in 1991. ## Career Fu started her career at the [Overseas Union Bank](/wiki/Overseas_Union_Bank) as an auditor from 1985 to 1988. She then joined the [Haw Par Group](/wiki/Haw_Par_Corporation), where she worked in corporate planning, financial control and business development from 1991 to 1995. In October 1995, Fu joined [PSA Corporation](/wiki/PSA_International) as Assistant Director (Finance). She took on additional responsibility as Vice-President (Marketing), and assumed the position of Financial Controller in October 1998. She was promoted to Executive Vice-President (Finance) in January 1999. In April 2003, Fu was appointed CEO of Singapore Terminals. In 2004, she became CEO of PSA South East Asia and Japan, where she was responsible for the business performance of PSA's flagship terminals in Singapore, Thailand, Brunei, and Japan. Fu has been a non-practising member of the [Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants](/wiki/Institute_of_Singapore_Chartered_Accountants) since 1992. On 5 January 2024, Fu was elected as the President of the [Singapore National Olympic Council](/wiki/Singapore_National_Olympic_Council). [Tan Chuan-Jin](/wiki/Tan_Chuan-Jin), the previous president and [Speaker of Parliament](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Parliament_of_Singapore), had resigned after an extramarital affair with fellow PAP MP [Cheng Li Hui](/wiki/Cheng_Li_Hui). ## Political career This article **needs additional citations for verification**. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Grace Fu" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(November 2025)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* Fu made her political debut in the [2006 general election](/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election) as part of the five-member PAP team contesting in [Jurong GRC](/wiki/Jurong_Group_Representation_Constituency) and won. Fu was subsequently elected as the Member of Parliament (MP) representing the [Yuhua](/wiki/Yuhua,_Singapore) division of Jurong GRC in June 2006. She was one of 24 new PAP candidates introduced ahead of the general election. On 1 August 2006, Fu was appointed [Minister of State for National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)). On 1 April 2008, Fu was promoted to Senior Minister of State for National Development, and appointed [Senior Minister of State for Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)) concurrently. At the [2011 general election](/wiki/2011_Singaporean_general_election), Fu contested in the newly created [Yuhua SMC](/wiki/Yuhua_Single_Member_Constituency) and won with 66.9% of the vote. Following the election, Fu was appointed [Senior Minister of State for Information, Communications and the Arts](/wiki/Ministry_of_Information,_Communications_and_the_Arts), and [Senior Minister of State for the Environment and Water Resources](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_and_Water_Resources) concurrently. In January 2012, Fu expressed concerns over the [planned 36–37% income cuts for ministers](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore#2011_review), saying that if ministerial pay was further reduced in the future, it would "make it harder for anyone considering political office". Her comments contributed to the public debate over the compensation and motivation of public officials, and were criticised by Singaporean netizens. Others defended her remark as fair, supporting her position that the loss of privacy and public scrutiny added to a large personal cost to working in public positions not found in the private sector. On 31 July 2012, Fu was made full minister, becoming the second woman in Singapore's history, after [Lim Hwee Hua](/wiki/Lim_Hwee_Hua), to become a full minister in the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore). She served as [Minister in the Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_(Singapore)), Second Minister for the Environment and Water Resources, and [Second Minister for Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Singapore)) from 2012 to 2015. In 2014, as the Minister in the Prime Minister's Office, Fu was in charge of the [Municipal Services Office](/wiki/Municipal_Services_Office_(Singapore)). In 2015, Fu was appointed [Minister for Culture, Community and Youth](/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture,_Community_and_Youth#Ministers), becoming the first female minister in Singapore to head a ministry. Following the [2020 general election](/wiki/2020_Singaporean_general_election), Fu became Organising Secretary of the PAP's [Central Executive Committee](/wiki/Central_Executive_Committee_(PAP)) (CEC). Fu served as [Leader of the House](/wiki/Leader_of_the_House_(Singapore)) from 2015 to 2020, before being appointed [Minister for Sustainability and the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment) in 2020. She has also been a member of the [Global Leaders Group on Antimicrobial Resistance](/wiki/Global_Leaders_Group_on_Antimicrobial_Resistance), co-chaired by Prime Minister of Bangladesh [Sheikh Hasina](/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina), and Prime Minister of Barbados [Mia Mottley](/wiki/Mia_Mottley), since 2020. On 14 January 2024, Fu became Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations after a cabinet reshuffle. [S. Iswaran](/wiki/S._Iswaran) had previously held the position, as well as the [ministership for transport](/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_(Singapore)), before [he resigned](/wiki/Prosecution_of_S._Iswaran) in response to being prosecuted on 27 charges of corruption. ## Personal life Fu's father, James Fu, was a former leftist journalist who became press secretary to Prime Minister [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew). Her mother was a nurse. Her grandmother, [Liew Yuen Sien](/wiki/Liew_Yuen_Sien), was the principal of [Nanyang Girls' High School](/wiki/Nanyang_Girls%27_High_School) from 1927 to 1966. Fu is married to Ivan Lee, a technology entrepreneur; they have three sons. ## Notes - Grace Fu on Prime Minister's Office - Grace Fu on [Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) - Grace Fu on [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook_(identifier)) Political officesPreceded by[Lim Swee Say](/wiki/Lim_Swee_Say) [S.
